PETITION.TITLE: Marriage
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Marriage
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned citizens of Australia
Concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown,
Convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union; and
Believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened
Humbly petition for the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act to be amended in order to
(1) Reject any moves towards divorce by post
(2) Restore the former prohibition of marriages between close relatives by blood or by marriage
(3) Protect the rights and welfare of aggrieved partners of a marriage who are threatened with being divorced against their will
(4) Ensure that in divorce judgments paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependent children of the marriage
(5) Encourage counselling towards reconciliation
(6) Restore objective tests of irretrievable breakdown of marriage in terms of: i. intolerable behaviour; ii. desertion for two years; iii. separation for three years.
We pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. The concerns which people around the World have for the increasing stockpiles of weapons of mass destruction;
2. The global concern that any nuclear exchange will inflict on humanity unimaginable death and suffering;
3. The vulnerability that Australians will face in any nuclear conflict between the major powers;
4. The public concern that Government should explore all avenues to ensure that the nuclear threat is eliminated.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament establish a Senate Select Committee on Nuclear Disarmament and Peace to investigate the creation of a Ministry of Peace and Nuclear Disarmament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Excise on Grape Spirit
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the 1983 Budget imposition of the excise on grape spirit used in fortifying wine places at risk the future of the fortified wine industry in Australia.
That the requirement to pay the excise within 7 days of the fortification occurring is inequitable.
That the excise will be reflected in increased costs to the consumers of fortified wines of up to 100 per cent and consumer choice will be restricted.
That this will cause reduced fortified wine sales which will result in reduced intake of grapes from grapegrowers.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will reconsider their previous decision and either withdraw this tax or modify its method of application and collection.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the speech which the Prime Minister gave to the Australian Council of Trade Unions Congress yesterday and in which he stressed the need for wage restraint within the bounds of the wages accord and opposed sectional wage rises. Does not the Budget indicate and does not Mr Willis confirm that even if the unions accept Mr Hawke's plea-of course, settlements in the building, food processing and oil industries make that prospect unlikely-and even if the accord holds, unemployment will continue to rise during the rest of this financial year and indeed in calendar year 1984? Does he agree that if the unions do not stick to the accord there will be an even higher rise in the amount of unemployment in Australia?

—The answer to the last part of the question is, in my view, yes. I am not sure that I can give an unqualified answer to the second last part of the question-I think there were two parts-that is, whether it is explicit in the Budget statements that unemployment will continue to rise. The scenarios which were posited both at the National Economic Summit Conference and in the Budget are subject to a number of variables, including any government action positively to stimulate employment in particular areas. Having made those qualifications, I think it is at least implicit in those statements that very high levels of unemployment will continue.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. What factors were involved in the Government's decision not to compensate Victoria for the revenue lost to the State because of the decision of the High Court of Australia on the pipeline duty? Secondly, as consumers will be affected by this in the forthcoming Cain Budget, can they expect a reduction in prices now that the duty has been ruled illegal?

—I was not involved in the discussions between the Treasurer, I think the Prime Minister, and the Victorian Government in relation to this matter. But I understand the importance of the question for the State of Victoria and I will seek to obtain an early answer from the Treasurer.
—My question is addressed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Is it the Government's intention to abolish or downgrade the National Women's Advisory Council?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been the intention of the Government since our days in opposition to replace the Advisory Council with a more broadly based consultative mechanism. We are now consulting with national women's organisations that will be meeting with the Office of the Status of Women this month and with other bodies, including the National Women's Advisory Council, to see how we can develop a mechanism whereby women, whatever their circumstances and whatever part of Australia they live in, have an opportunity to put their views to government.

ANSWER.PARA: In implementing this decision of developing a more broadly based consultative mechanism, the Government acknowledges the excellent work which has been done by the Council or various councils over the years, particularly in some of the research projects they have funded. It also acknowledges the individual efforts of women who have been members of that Council. However, it has been very clear to us and, I believe, to most other people who have taken an interest in these matters that a council of 12 or 14 women is not extensive enough to provide to government the diversity of views which exist among Australian women today. We are open to suggestions as to how to develop and implement a new broadly based consultative mechanism. That invitation can be extended to the Opposition if it has any constructive suggestions it would like to make.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, my question is directed to you. I refer you to the statement made by Senator Chipp on 31 May this year, and reported in the Press the next day, that several people had attempted to bribe Australian Democrat senators to influence their votes on the unpaid company tax legislation which was then before the Senate. Senator Chipp made it clear at the time that he had rejected outright these attempted bribes and that they had not influenced either his vote or the votes of other Australian Democrat senators on the legislation in question. I ask you, Mr President, whether you will investigate these unsuccessful attempts to bribe senators in order to determine whether they might constitute a breach of privilege.

—It is not my responsibility-it is that of the Senate-to determine whether any matter of the nature referred to in the honourable senator's question should be investigated. Should the honourable senator wish to raise it as a matter of privilege, procedures are laid down within the Standing Orders of the Senate for him, or indeed for any other honourable senator, to do so. But in saying that, I point out-I think my recollection is correct-that at the time of those newspaper reports Senator Chipp said that he did not know the indentity of the people who might have been involved. I would assume, therefore, that that sort of statement by Senator Chipp would be taken into account by the Senate in determining whether any breach of privilege did or did not take place.

—I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer a question concerning the current welcome decline in interest rates. While one can commend this development, is not one of the reasons for it that savings banks are presently awash with money, their deposits having increased by over 20 per cent in the past 12 months? As this clearly represents a lack of confidence on the part of people in the future, inducing a desire to save money rather than spend it, will the Minister agree that it should be government and opposition policy to create a feeling of confidence in the community so that a consumer-led recovery might become feasible? To encourage such an upward movement in consumer spending, will the Government contemplate some mildly expansionary policies such as the abolition of payroll tax and the provision of real tax cuts for low and middle income earners?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly the Government welcomes the significant decline in interest rates which has been announced over the last week or so. I think it is fair to acknowledge simultaneously that the factor to which Senator Chipp drew attention-that is, savings banks and some other institutions being awash with money-is one of the reasons for that decline. It is, of course, also highly desirable that confidence be maintained at the highest level which can be reasonably expected. It would be helpful if the Opposition were to put the welfare of the Australian people and the health of the economy ahead of politicking. Helpful though that would be, experience suggests that it is not likely to occur.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the final part of Senator Chipp's question, the factor of confidence is also relevant. He suggested the abolition of payroll tax as one possibility. I think total payroll tax collections are now in excess of $2 billion. It is an extremely large item. Payroll tax, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory, of course, is imposed by the States. While various States have expressed the desire to abolish payroll tax they have usually added to that expression of desire the qualification 'provided the Commonwealth provides commensurate revenue'. Ultimately, that would require a $2 billion increase in Commonwealth expenditure via grants to the States. That is a very significant change to Commonwealth Government finances. Real tax cuts for low and middle income earners also would have some stimulatory effects; they would also, of course, have effects on government revenue. Both of the propositions which Senator Chipp has suggested would have the effect of increasing the deficit, perhaps by a very large amount.

TALK.START.PARA: —So what?

—I was about to come to the question of the deficit and to deal with the point of confidence. Statistical tables presented by institutions like the Melbourne Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research and also by some economic journalists have analysed the components of demand and the likely effect of that on growth rates and, therefore, employment in the current financial year. They have argued that there is a case for a larger Budget deficit. These matters are, of course, in the end matters of judgment. Although the evidence to support the belief that there is a direct linkage between the size of the deficit and interest rates, inflationary expectations and business confidence might be indecisive, in the judgment of the Government there is a widely held perception, in the business community in particular, that that is so and that business confidence and consumer confidence are of equal importance. The judgment made by the Government between the conflicting arguments put forward by the Melbourne Institute, for example, and the business community on the potentially damaging effect on business confidence of a larger deficit was that the deficit originally suggested at the April National Economic Summit Conference of $8.5 billion was the appropriate one to choose.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I ask: How often is it necessary for the Department of Health form NH5 to be submitted to the Commonwealth Department of Health in relation to a person whose admission to a nursing home has been approved? Has any investigation been made to see whether the period between reports may be extended? If so, what has been the result of those investigations? Finally, would it be possible to revise form NH5 to make it necessary to provide information only if the patient's condition or circumstances have changed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Colston has asked about the form NH5, which is the form required by the Department of Health to be completed prior to someone being admitted to a nursing home. The form contains certification from the patient's doctor outlining the reasons why such a person requires nursing home accommodation. In some cases of emergency, interim admission can be approved but the form certainly has to be filled out later. Currently, this form remains in effect for 56 days, in which time the person or his family must try to find suitable nursing home accommodation. If it is not possible within that time to find a place for the person, a new form must be submitted. While in most cases the submission of such a new form would not be necessary, I can certainly see that there would be annoyance where a family had been seeking placement, say for an elderly relative, for something like two months and then had to go through that admission procedure again. I assume that that is Senator Colston's concern. However, under the current system, where we rely on the production of certificates like this for approving nursing home admission, it is appropriate after a reasonable length of time for the Government or the Department to require a new certification that the person seeking such accommodation still requires it.

ANSWER.PARA: The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure investigated accommodation and home care for the aged and discovered that some 20 to 25 per cent of the people in nursing home accommodation in fact should not be there. The simple fact is that we will not be able to do much about improving that situation unless we have some means of assessing whether people should be in a nursing home, this being the most expensive form of accommodation. So we would hope in the future to introduce a better and more reasonable form of assessment for people in this area.

The Department has been running an evaluation study in recent years which has involved a nurse seeing people just prior to their admission to nursing homes. The study resulted in something like 5 per cent of applications being rejected and more suitable accommodation being found. This year the Government has allocated some $2m for the development of community based geriatric assessment centres both in Dr Blewett's Department of Health and in the Department of Veterans' Affairs, under Senator Gietzelt. We have a real commitment to providing a better system of assessment in the future and I certainly hope that that system of assessment will do away with the problem of having local doctors filling out NH5 bits of paper to give people the right, one way or another, to receive the assistance they need in nursing home accommodation. So, as the new system replaces the old system, I think we will find that the situation is more satisfactory. We will certainly find that more accommodation of this type is available for those who need it, which is the important thing, and, therefore, minor annoyances like having to fill out a new NH5 form every 56 days or so will disappear from the system.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I draw the Minister's attention to a report given by the Anti-Slavery Society for the Protection of Human Rights to a United Nations body in Geneva on 10 August 1983, claiming that up to 200,000 West Papuans have been killed since Indonesia invaded West Papua in 1962 and created the state of Indonesian New Guinea, or Irian Jaya, and that an estimated one million Indonesians, principally from the over-populated island of Java, are being resettled in West Papua on the traditional lands of the natives who are being forced out. In the light of this disturbing report and the concern expressed by Ministers of the Vanuatuan Government to me during my recent visit there that the Papua New Guinea Government is not sufficiently standing up to Indonesia in the protection of the indigenous Melanesian population of West Papua, I ask the Minister: Firstly, will the Government make available to the Parliament any information that it may have on the alleged involvement of Indonesian troops in the many disappearances and executions of native Melanesians; secondly, has the Australian Government raised with the Indonesian Government complaints that the indigenous inhabitants have been deprived of their traditional lands in favour of Indonesian colonists; and, thirdly, will Australia work in co-operation with other Pacific nations to defend the human rights and traditional lands of the indigenous Melanesians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some information on the subject to which Senator Missen referred. I am not sure that I will be in a position to answer all of his questions. But those of them that I do not answer I will follow up in due course .

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is aware of allegations by the London-based Anti-Slavery Society concerning human rights abuses of the Melanesian population in Irian Jaya. The Government has no information from its own sources on these allegations. The Government is aware that the Indonesian Government has, for some years, of course, been relocating people from densely populated Java to its more sparsely populated outer islands and territories including Irian Jaya. The recently announced five-year plan for 1984-89 involves a total of some five million transmigrants of whom one million are to settle in Irian Jaya.

The Australian Government believes that the rights of indigenous populations deserve greater international attention. Australia was instrumental in the establishment of the United Nations working group on indigenous populations in 1982 and has participated, as an active observer, in the group's first two annual sessions. The 1983 meeting took place in Geneva last month, as the honourable senator indicated. The Government considers that the working group referred to offers the best prospects for effective multilateral consideration of the complex issues involved in Irian Jaya. It goes without saying that indigenous populations in many countries have historically been subject to disposition and dispersal. The drafting of an internationally accepted set of standards to protect indigenous rights, which is the principal task of this working group, should make a major contribution to promoting indigenous welfare on a global basis.

In view of the reports which the Government has seen through the Minister for Foreign Affairs of the Melanesian inhabitants of Irian Jaya experiencing difficulties as a result of the cultural and legal problems created by transmigration and, perhaps, some other kind of problems as well, the Minister for Foreign Affairs has advised me that he has asked Australian diplomatic missions in Geneva, Jakarta and London to seek further information on the matters in issue.

We will keep Parliament advised as appropriate. I certainly will produce any further information that I can in response to the specific matters that have been raised by Senator Missen when that further information is received.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Social Security aware that the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow Minister for Social Security have made statements promising to reverse the assets test which the Government foreshadowed in the Budget? What is the Minister's view of their opposition to the Australian Labor Party Government's assets test while refusing to commit themselves to a promise that they would not introduce an assets test of their own?

—I raise a point of order. The question is not related to a matter which is within the administration of this Minister. The question is aimed at the attitudes of the Opposition. The then Opposition frequently took points of order when similar questions were asked of Liberal Ministers in this place. I submit that the question is not in order.

—I wish to speak to the point of order. It seemed to me, as I heard Senator Zakharov's question, that she was asking what my attitude and therefore, what the Government's attitude, was to the Opposition's stated policy of opposing an assets test proposed by the Government but wanting to introduce its own. I think that is well within the purview of Question Time as similar questions have been accepted in the past and certainly in my time.

—I wish to speak on the point of order and answer Senator Grimes . He is obviously trying to pull the wool over everybody's eyes by stating quite clearly the Government's opinion. That is the very point to which Senator Chaney drew your attention, Mr President.
—I think the question could have been a little better expressed. As it related to the Government's attitude I shall allow Senator Grimes to respond.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week during Question Time I was asked about the policy of the Opposition in announcing that it would repeal the assets test legislation passed by this Government which the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow Minister for Social Security have not seen and the policy that the Opposition would repeal legislation providing for a change in the taxation of superannuation benefits which those gentlemen have also not seen in detail. I thought at the time that the policy as espoused by the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow Minister for Social Security was in fact a firm policy. I pointed out at the time that I was severely critical of people who, claiming they still had to develop their own policy, closed off their options in this way by opposing any such moves by the Government to introduce an assets test or to change the superannuation means test. We now find, of course, as was predicted in this place last week, that one could not take that comment seriously.

ANSWER.PARA: I will take the unusual step, perhaps the unique step in this Parliament for someone on this side of the House, of quoting that political commentator and broadcaster, John Laws. I will do so to demonstrate what someone who certainly could not be considered a Labor supporter in this country says about this matter . In the weekend Press he said:

Take one political 'con', couch it in much ballyhoo, with a dash of social conscience, and you have the Liberal Party's announcement that, if returned to office, it would toss out Labor's assets tests on pensions.

The reason Mr Laws used those words, as he went on to describe later in his article, was that he questioned both the shadow Minister for Social Security, Senator Messner, and Senator Walsh's friend, the former Treasurer, Mr Howard, both of whom said that, although they may oppose Labor's assets test, it did not mean that they would not introduce one themselves. In fact, Mr Howard implied that they would certainly so do. When asked by Mr Laws, Senator Messner refused to give a firm public promise not to introduce an assets test. He replied that he was unable to make such a commitment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. This answer in no way meets the indication that the Minister gave when he was responding to the previous point of order. All he is doing is proceeding to quote other people's comments on the Opposition. It is not an answer to the question and it is not in accordance with the line of answer which he indicated to you and which you ruled was in order.

—I draw the Minister's attention to standing order 100, which says that in responding to questions a senator shall not debate the matter to which the question refers. I would ask the Minister to relate his answer to the administration of his Department.

—The fact is, Mr President, that having reported the facts as they are, I merely wish to demonstrate to this House that the announcement by the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow Minister for Social Security of their opposition to the Government moves was in fact a phoney announcement. In fact, they have no intention of getting away from this sort of policy. I think the reaction, twice during this question, of the Leader of the Opposition demonstrates what I have been talking about during previous Question Times and now.

—My question, which is not a dorothy dixer, is directed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce. Does the Minister agree with the statement reported in today's Australian Financial Review and elsewhere as having been made yesterday by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, that the forms of protection existing in Australia 'are in fact, embalming geriatric industries in the formaldehyde of protection'? If the Minister does not agree with the statement by the former Leader of the Australian Labor Party, in what way does he disagree and would he express his own view in relation to that matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see the remarks made by the former Leader of the Labor Party, Mr Hayden.
—We will send you a copy.

—There is no need, thank you. If the honourable senator had been listening he would know that I said I did see the remarks made by Mr Hayden. In fact, it was very difficult not to. I simply take the view that Mr Hayden was expressing a long term view of this matter; in fact a long term view which is held by both political parties. The Government has clearly indicated its shorter term view in relation to these matters. If Senator Rae wishes me to reiterate it , I shall. The Government came to office undertaking that there would be no general reductions in protection in the period of the current economic downturn, that schemes in relation to particular industries which provided for phased reductions of protection would be kept in place, and that in the longer term the Government would look to a more general reduction in protection at the same time as, or subsequent to, setting in place a number of more positive industry assistance measures, which the Government is in the process of doing.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not think I can take the answer any further than that. I note Mr Hayden's views and, couched as they are in colourful language, I think they must be regarded as views which may be appropriate for some future time and views which are coloured by the Minister's frequent visits to South East Asia.

TALK.START.PARA: —How long is 'long term'?

—I shall not respond at Question Time to every idiotic interjection that I receive, Mr President. However, in the context of the remarks made by Mr Hayden, the Government is continuing a policy which has been announced and repeated on a number of occasions.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Since the Minister so obviously disagrees with the Minister for Foreign Affairs in relation to protection and the short term interests of Australia and says that the views expressed by the Minister for Foreign Affairs could be applicable only in the long term, will the Minister indicate what he means by 'short term' and ' long term'?

—In the answer to the original question I indicated that the Government had given a commitment at the time of the election, which it was maintaining, that apart from systems providing for phased reductions in protection, there would be no general reduction in protection in the current economic circumstances which we inherited. I am not putting on my seer's hat in order to define, in the Senate or anywhere else, what 'long term' means having regard to those circumstances; but as soon as practicable, the Government will pursue the policies which I have announced.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to recent claims by adult unemployed groups in South Australia that funding arrangements for self-help and support programs for the adult unemployed are totally inadequate. Is the Minister of the opinion that the existing programs administered by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations are totally inadequate to meet the needs of unemployed adults? Will the Minister consider increasing the level of assistance to self-help projects for the adult unemployed as a means of overcoming the difficulties now being experienced by these groups?

—In a general sense, I suppose that one must say that all schemes of assistance for the unemployed are inadequate. But having said that, I am aware that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has received representations from the State of South Australia about the question of mature age unemployed and the support schemes which are available to them. I understand that some funding is provided by the South Australian Government specifically for these groups. One suggestion from South Australia was that the community youth employment program should be extended to cover mature age unemployed persons. The Government is not persuaded to that view because the needs of unemployed persons of mature age are likely, I think, to be different from those of much younger age groups. A number of proposals from South Australia have been forwarded to the Minister and I am advised that the Minister has asked his Department to consider those representations. I remind the honourable senator that at present a number of programs are administered by the Commonwealth to provide assistance to the unemployed, including the community employment program and the labour adjustment training programs. There are a number of other similar measures which I cannot identify or enumerate at this time but I will be happy to do so if the honourable senator wishes. The representations are receiving consideration.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry whether it is a fact that in the nine months to March 1983, 3,272 kilograms of lamb and sheep meat were imported into Australia. Since then there have been dramatic increases. For example, for the month of March alone imports were more than four-fold those of the previous nine-month period and the preliminary figure of 566,099 kilograms for the month of July was twice the figure for June. I ask: What impact have these increases had on declining saleyard prices in Australia? Can we expect these dramatic increases under the closer economic relations agreement with New Zealand to continue at such alarming rates?

—Off the top of my head I am not able to verify those figures which Senator Watson has quoted. If there has been an increase in imports of sheep meat that could well be attributable to the effects of the drought in Australia. I will refer that aspect to the Minister for Primary Industry for his comment. As to the final part of Senator Watson's question, I am not able to say what effect the imports have had on saleyard prices but, whatever effect they have had, one would expect that they would have had the same effect on retail prices. In other words, if imports have brought down the saleyard prices of livestock they have also brought down meat prices at the retail level. I will refer the other matters to the Minister and supply an answer as quickly as possible.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, arises out of the announcement yesterday by the Government of an inquiry into the national road freight industry. Will this inquiry be able to compare the advantages of drivers employed on wages over owner-drivers? Will the effect of tight scheduling of freight services which often requires drivers to exceed the speed limit in order to keep their jobs be considered? Will the unfortunate but extensive use of drugs by drivers to stay awake on long haul routes be examined? What other things does the Government hope to achieve from the inquiry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook asked me a question about the announcement made yesterday by the Hon. Peter Morris, the Minister for Transport, of the establishment of a national road freight industry inquiry which will comprise Mr Thomas May, Professor Gordon Mills and Mr Scully, three persons capable of carrying out a fundamental review of the facts relating to the road and freight transport industry generally. This will probably emerge as an extremely important inquiry which will look into both road and rail services in Australia. The purpose of the inquiry is to look at all the matters which affect the industry, including those that have been raised in the question from Senator Cook. It will look at the ability of the industry to provide an efficient, economic service, the impact of regulations as they exist at both Federal and State levels and the competition between road and rail. It will certainly look at the increased involvement of heavy vehicles in motor crashes and what that means to the industry as well as to the community generally. It will look at the problems of competition in the industry and its effects upon the prices structure in the whole freight transport industry. Of course that will involve looking also at the pricing structures so far as trucks in the heavy industry area are concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: It is interesting that the Minister has been able to get the support of all the State governments, including the Northern Territory. When the inquiry has completed its investigations, I think we will have a much better understanding of what has been a very big growth factor in Australia in the post war years, particularly in the last 20 years. We will be able to have the facts, the figures and the ideas necessary so that governments generally will be able to apply themselves to a more efficient transport industry in Australia and perhaps overcome some of the losses that exist in the private sector and the effects that they have upon the economy. As well governments will be able to examine the cost problems that face many of our public transport systems, particularly rail transport. I am assuring the honourable senator that what the Minister and the Government have in mind is a cost effective inquiry which will considerably assist this industry by properly examining costs and potential savings.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I address my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It was reported today that, whilst the Prime Minister was addressing the Australian Council of Trade Unions Congress yesterday, 18 unions distributed a document calling for further changes to be made to the superannuation tax proposals. Is the Minister in a position to advise what the central point of those changes is and whether the Government has yet responded to it?

—I am not in a position to say what the burden of those representations is. I am not surprised that 18 unions distributed a document and I do not know what the implication of the honourable senator's question is on that point. We certainly could not stop them doing that if we wanted to. There is concern amongst some unions about the superannuation lump sum proposals, and that concern is presumably being expressed in that way. If I do find out what is in the document, I will let the honourable senator know.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Communications whether the 0-10 television network has exclusive rights to cover the America's Cup race that begins on Wednesday, 14 September 1983. Have any arrangements been made to feed this telecast beyond the transmission range of the purely metropolitan 0-10 network via the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to allow remote areas and provincial city areas throughout Australia to see Australia II win the America's Cup?

—I understand that the 0-10 network has the exclusive rights to transmission of the America's Cup. By the time it ultimately comes on I think the average Australian viewer will be so bored he probably will not want to watch it.
—You must be joking.

—I refer only to the fact that it has received enormous coverage on all channels, Senator. The important point of Senator Jones's question is whether the ABC has negotiated with the 0-10 network to obtain the coverage of the America's Cup for those living in remote areas where the ABC provides the only television transmission. I am not able to answer that question, but I hope and believe that the ABC has sought negotiations with the 0-10 network. I will provide the honourable senator with a more comprehensive answer from the Minister as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. As the world is casting round to seek some method of underlining the horrendous action of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics in the murder of the 269 passengers and crew of the Korean airliner, and because the USSR has issued a warning to the world that any aircraft flying over its territory can expect the same sort of action, I ask the Leader of the Government: Will he ask the Prime Minister to consider putting to the Government of the United States of America that that country prohibit the entry of the Russian athletes to the Olympic Games which are to be held next year in America? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator raised a complex matter which has quite a long history. The best starting point in explanation probably would be the 1967 Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act, which established, in areas which were off- shore to all the States, joint authorities which laid down both the quantity and the distribution of royalties for oil which may be found off-shore. In the case of the Northern Territory, which was not self-governing at that stage, the Commonwealth retained as Commonwealth territory the sea area adjoining the Northern Territory. The Seas and Submerged Lands Act 1973 asserted Commonwealth sovereignty beyond the low water mark. That legislation was taken on appeal to the High Court of Australia. In 1975 the High Court found in favour of the Commonwealth.

ANSWER.PARA: There the situation rested until 1979, when the previous Government handed back to the States what was called the territorial sea, which was three miles off- shore. In a few instances it was somewhat more than three miles. That Government amended the 1967 Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act to retain the joint authority arrangements for the management of the ocean area and ocean floor beyond three miles, whilst ensuring that ultimate control, in the event of a dispute in a joint authority, rested with the Commonwealth. Also in 1979 the Commonwealth- presumably because by then the Northern Territory had become self-governing- allocated to the joint authority of the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory almost all of the 200-mile zone which previously had been entirely Commonwealth territory. Because of the 1979 package of legislation the Northern Territory, for this purpose, acquired the status of a State. However, at that time a portion of the ocean area in question, known as the Ashmore and Cartier Islands, which had previously been Commonwealth territory, was excluded from that part of the Commonwealth territory which was transferred, for purposes of management by a joint authority, to the Northern Territory.

At the end of that recital of the historical and factual background is the fact that the Ashmore and Cartier Islands area, within which the Jabiru 1A well was drilled, the results of which were announced by the Broken Hill Proprietary Co Ltd, I think, on 30 August, is entirely in Commonwealth territory, since constitutionally everything below the three-mile limit as adjusted is Commonwealth territory but, legislatively, all but the Ashmore and Cartier Islands ocean area is subject to the joint authority and stipulated royalty charges and royalty distribution between the States and the Commonwealth. The Ashmore and Cartier Islands area, within which this oil well was drilled, the results of which were announced by the company, is entirely within Commonwealth territory and not subject to the jurisdiction of the 1967 Act and, therefore, not subject to either the royalty charges stipulated in the 1967 Act or the distribution of those charges between the Commonwealth and any State or Territory.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON CONSTITUTIONAL AND LEGAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, I present a report dated September 1983 on an examination of the feasibility of a compact or Makarrata between the Commonwealth and the Aboriginal people, together with the transcript of evidence .

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

I table today a report from the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, entitled 'Two Hundred Years Later . . . ' The report is a result of a resolution of the Senate that the Committee should conduct 'an examination of the feasibility, whether by way of constitutional amendment or other legal means , of securing a compact or 'Makarrata' between the Commonwealth Government and Aboriginal Australians.'

IntroductionProposals for some form of treaty or compact or, to use the word favoured by the National Aboriginal Conference, a 'Makarrata', have had currency for several years. The idea behind such proposals is that at this stage of Australia's history there is a need for a reappraisal of traditional perceptions of the historical relationship between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people from the time of European settlement in this country. Proponents of the concept have argued that the best means of effecting a reconciliation between the Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal communities is the negotiation of a comprehensive agreement setting to rights, insofar as that is possible some two hundred years later, the dispossession and ill-treatment suffered by the original inhabitants of this continent and their descendants at the time of European settlement and subsequently.

It is important to emphasise that the Committee's terms of reference did not require it to come to a conclusion as to the desirability or usefulness of the Makarrata concept. That central issue must be decided elsewhere and by other persons, the appropriate representatives of the Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal communities. Clearly such an agreement would only succeed if it were understood and supported throughout the whole Australian community. As regards the Aboriginal community there must be a comprehensive consultative process throughout Australia, an understanding and systematic consideration of the legal issues involved and of the various legal options for implementation. As well, there must be clear accord as to the objectives which are sought to be procured by the agreement, the establishment of proper representational processes and of a timetable for implementation. The relevance to the narrower question of legal feasibility of these issues which must be dealt with if a decision is made to pursue a compact became apparent during the course of the inquiry and the Committee's report attempts to assist in consideration of them.

Legal feasibilityWithin the area of legal feasibility, issues which the report considers include whether the Aboriginal people's claim to sovereignty can be upheld, whether a compact with constitutional backing is desirable and, if so, whether the full text or just a broad enabling power should be included within the Constitution. Other alternatives to be considered are whether the compact should be supported by legislation based on the Commonwealth's existing constitutional authority or should take the form of a simple agreement or contract.

The claim made by some Aboriginals to sovereignty is given serious and detailed consideration in the report. The Committee looked closely at the rules of international law regarding sovereignty and at the consistent application by the courts in Australia of the 'settled colony' principle which in turn was based on the 'terra nullius' doctrine by which it was held that at the time of European settlement Australia was land belonging to no one. The effect of the application of this principle was that the Aboriginal inhabitants of the colony of Australia became immediately subject to the laws of the colonising nation which refused to acknowledge that they had a recognisable system of law and disregarded their relationship to their land.

However regrettable and ill-founded the views which led to the application of the settled colony principle with its historical consequences for the Aboriginal people, the Committee has concluded that sovereignty does not now inhere in the Aboriginal people. The Committee's conclusion is expressed in the following terms:

It may be that a better and more honest appreciation of the facts relating to Aboriginal occupation at the time of settlement, and of the Eurocentric view taken by the occupying power could lead to the conclusion that sovereignty inhered in the Aboriginal peoples at that time. However, the Committee concludes that, as a legal proposition, sovereignty is not now vested in the Aboriginal peoples except insofar as they share in the common sovereignty of all peoples of the Commonwealth of Australia. In particular, they are not a sovereign entity under our present law so that they can enter into a treaty with the Commonwealth . Nevertheless, the Committee is of the view that if it is recognised that sovereignty did adhere in the Aboriginal people in a way not comprehended by those who applied the terra nullius doctrine at the time of occupation and settlement, then certain consequences flow which are proper to be dealt with in a compact between the descendants of those Aboriginal peoples and other Australians.

Following its consideration of the legal options available to implement a compact, the Committee concludes that the option to be preferred is the insertion within the Constitution of a provision similar to existing section 105A of the Constitution and recommends that the Goverment, in consultation with the Aboriginal people, should give consideration to this option if a compact is pursued. Under this option, a new provision in the Constitution would confer a broad power on the Commonwealth enabling it to enter into a compact with representatives of the Aboriginal people. The provision would contain a non- exclusive list of those matters which would form an important part of the terms of the compact, expressing in broad language the types of subjects to be dealt with.

An important aspect of this approach is the symbolically important opportunity it would provide for the Australian people, by way of the necessary referendum to amend the Constitution, to show their commitment to the concept of a compact as a means of reconciliation between the Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal communities and as a means whereby the history of injustice and deprivation against Aboriginal people can in some measure be redressed. Inclusion of a special enabling power within the Constitution would also enhance the status of the ultimate agreement.

Although the Committee's preference is for a constitutional amendment, our consideration of sections 51 (xxvi) (the power to make laws for the people of any race for whom it is deemed necessary to make special laws) and 51 (xxix) ( the external affairs power) have led us to conclude that there already exists sufficient power to enable the Parliament to enact the sort of legislative measures which would be likely to flow from the conclusion of a compact. These powers, recently given detailed consideration by the High Court in Koowarta's Case and the Tasmanian Dam decision, would certainly provide a useful 'fall-back ' position should it be decided not to pursue a constitutional amendment.

RepresentationOne of the more significant issues which came to the Committee's attention during public hearings was that of representation. The question of who should represent the non-Aboriginal party in negotiations has never seriously been in issue and the Committee's reasons for supporting the Commonwealth Government in this role are set out in the report so I need not discuss them in this statement.

However, the question of who should represent the Aboriginal community is not so straightforward and has been the subject of much deliberation by the Committee. The National Aboriginal Conference has been the major proponent of a compact on behalf of Aborigines and has generally been seen as the body most suited to negotiate on their account. In our travels among Aboriginal communities we heard a good deal of comment about the NAC's inadequate funding and structure. For example, many witnesses spoke of the inability of the NAC to adequately represent Aboriginal viewpoints because of the smallness of its membership and the consequently large electorates to be served by each member. Concern was also expressed in some quarters about what was perceived as a lack of independence from government on the NAC's part.

The Committee has noted that the new Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has made it clear that the present government wishes to strengthen the NAC and enhance its role as the nationally elected body representing Aboriginal people in their dealings with the Commonwealth Government. As part of this new role the Minister has suggested that the NAC give consideration to a new structure for itself and that it consider its re-establishment under its own Act, thereby giving it the statutory autonomy it lacks at present. As well the recent Budget doubled the NAC's appropriation.

In view of these developments the Committee, while recognising that the decision ultimately rests with Aborigines themselves concludes that the NAC should be considered the most suitable organisation to co-ordinate Aboriginal opinion during the negotiation process and, once negotiations are completed, to conclude the compact on behalf of the Aboriginal people. To this end, the Committee urges the NAC to take the opportunity which the government has offered it to seek re-establishment on an independent statutory basis and with an increase in membership, so as to allow it to represent the Aboriginal people more effectively. We also urge the government, following its Budget initiative, to maintain funding of the NAC at a level which will enable it to fulfil adequately its enhanced role.

At the same time we emphasise that we see the NAC's role as one of co- ordination of Aboriginal opinion. There is a valuable role to be played by the many community-based Aboriginal organisations such as land councils and health, legal and housing services in educating, seeking views and relaying them to the negotiators if the compact proposal goes forward.

EducationAnother vital issue which the Committee has found it necessary to address in its report is that of education-among both the Aboriginal and non- Aboriginal communities-about the compact proposal. Before any compact could be concluded considerable thought would need to be devoted to the question of how to inform both communities about the concept, its purpose and effect.

The evidence available to the Committee indicated a widespread lack of information and understanding among Aboriginal communities of the idea of a compact. We also found that in some instances there was only a limited understanding even among informed non-Aboriginal witnesses, from which it could be inferred that the wider non-Aboriginal community also lacks an understanding of the idea. We wish to emphasise, however, that this lack of understanding should not be confused with hostility to the idea. Rather it indicates that the concept is a relatively recent one which requires explanation and discussion. Such discussion should include consideration of the desirability of a compact, its benefits and disadvantages, both present and future, and a consideration of alternative means to the same ends.

The Committee heard valuable suggestions from witnesses as to the most effective means of promoting education and discussion among Aboriginal communities, and these are considered in Chapter 9 of our report. Although likely to be time consuming, the Committee believes that such a process is crucial if a compact is to be negotiated. Accordingly, we recommend that, in order to ensure that the negotiation process is conducted on a basis of understanding and acceptance of the concept by all Aboriginal comunities, the Commonwealth should ensure that the widest range of Aboriginal community leadership is involved in that preliminary task.

The Committee also discusses the need for the development of programs under Commonwealth sponsorship to raise the consciousness of the non-Aboriginal community to a level where the compact proposal can be discussed in an informed way. The Committee recognises the political nature of this task, especially if the Committee's preferred option of a constitutional amendment is pursued. This would require widespread discussion and subsequent acceptance of the issues involved if the necessary majorities to amend the Constitution were to be attained.

ConclusionIn conclusion I emphasise again that this report is not concerned to determine whether the concept of a Makarrata should be pursued. What the report seeks to do is to address in detail a number of subsidiary issues which will need to be faced if the necessarily political decision to negotiate a compact is made by Aboriginal people and the Commonwealth. It is the Committee's hope that, if that decision is made, the report will be of assistance in coming to grips with the various processes which will need to be pursued if a worthwhile compact is to come to fruition.

During the course of this inquiry the Committee's membership changed considerably. When the Committee was re-constituted following the election in March, Senators Ryan, Evans and Crichton-Browne were replaced by Senators Bolkus , Cook and Lewis. I wish to record here my appreciation of the part played by the three Senators who left the Committee. They were present for almost all the public hearings and made a significant contribution to the Committee's early deliberations on this matter.

I also wish to commend the staff assisting the Commitee, particularly the Secretary, Mr Chris Fogarty, for their untiring work in supporting the preparation of this report over a long period disrupted by the dissolution of Parliament earlier this year.

Following the change of Government I, as a Government Senator, was elected Chairman of the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee to replace Senator Alan Missen who chaired the Committee with distinction for the period 1976-1983. This of course included much of the period of this inquiry. I wish to put on record the Committee's appreciation of Senator Missen's dedication and courtesy during the period of his chairmanship. Needless to say we value his continued membership on the Committee.
Mr President, I commend the report to the Senate.

The Government has a clear national responsibility to prepare contingency plans against a foreseeable national emergency. The fundamental objectives of a national response to a major fuel shortage should be to minimise the total impact on the community (in terms of maintaining essential services and minimising economic dislocation) and to ensure that available supplies are distributed as equitably as possible.

The purpose of this Bill is to equip the Commonwealth Government with the authority needed to prepare for, and handle a national liquid fuel supply emergency. This would be done in close co-operation with the Governments of the States and the Northern Territory.

In the event of a serious shortfall of fuel supplies it could be expected that fuel prices would tend to rise substantially as purchasers competed for available supplies. This would be exacerbated with panic buying and consequently normal market operations may break down. Such a situation could cause severe economic dislocation and hardship throughout the community. Government intervention to ensure a fair distribution of available fuel supplies may be required. For example, in a severe shortfall governments may need to implement quantitative allocation measures to achieve a satisfactory balance between supply and demand.
Governments will require flexibility in meeting an emergency. It is important to recognise that the most appropriate response would be determined in the light of prevailing conditions.

The provisions of this Bill will enable this to occur. Together with existing legislation in the States and the Northern Territory, its enactment will enable the Commonwealth to take action in a fuel supply emergency situation with the effectiveness and authority that the Australian community is entitled to expect. The passage of this Bill will represent a major step forward in the Commonwealth Government's preparations against a national liquid fuel supply emergency.

This Bill is one of the outcomes of a major effort by Commonwealth and State governments to improve their preparedness against a fuel shortage. It has its antecedents in the events of 1979, when the Iranian oil crisis triggered a condition of turmoil in world oil markets that forced an accelerated recognition of the need to prepare measures for dealing with an emergency situation. It was in this climate that member countries of the International Energy Agency became acutely aware of the possibility of having to implement the IEA's emergency oil sharing system and to invoke cut-backs in the consumption of liquid fuel in accordance with their obligations as IEA members. Australia, although a member of IEA, does not have the appropriate legal basis for handling a supply cut.

As a result of the concern of all Australians about the possible impact of uncertain supplies, in September 1979 Commonwealth and State Ministers with responsibility for energy matters agreed to the formation of the National Petroleum Advisory Committee to advise governments on the appropriate arrangements and priorities for the allocation of liquid fuels during any period of supply shortfall.

NPAC members are drawn from the agricultural, fishing, manufacturing, mining, shipping and transport industries, the oil industry, Australian Council of Trade Unions and motorists' organisations as well as the Commonwealth, State and Northern Territory Governments.

NPAC completed its report 'management of a national liquid fuels supply emergency' in October 1981 and after acceptance by Commonwealth, State and Territory governments as a basis for proceeding with emergency planning, the report was tabled in the Parliament on 16 September 1982.

The proposed Bill is in accordance with the NPAC recommendations and is based closely on the powers proposed in the report. Together with current legislation in the States and the Northern Territory, it will enable all governments to work together in preparing for and managing a national liquid fuel emergency.

In order to meet, as far as possible, the concern expressed by some States that the proposed Bill may inhibit the operation of their own emergency legislation, I have agreed that the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory shall work together to develop alternative Commonwealth and State legislation. To provide a specific time frame for this exercise I have also agreed to include in the proposed Bill a three year 'sunset clause'. This will enable discussions to proceed without jeopardising the Commonwealth's ability to act decisively in any emergency situation in the immediate future. I recognise that agreement with the States on alternative legislation cannot be guaranteed within the three-year period. In this event, it would be necessary to extend the Act beyond the currently proposed sunset date.

It is our intention to work in conjunction with the State and Territory governments. The Bill requires that consultations occur between the Commonwealth and State and Territory energy Ministers before declaration by the Governor- General of a national liquid fuel emergency. Consultation is also required before the Commonwealth Minister may make certain determinations or issue certain directions under this Bill. These include actions under the contingency planning and the emergency control clauses of the Bill. Further, the Bill enables the Commonwealth Minister to delegate powers to the State and Territory Ministers where this is appropriate. The primary mechanism for consultation will be the establishment of a high level committee of Commonwealth, State and Territory officials as the National Fuel Emergency Consultative Committee. This was recommended by NPAC and I have taken steps to establish this Committee through an exchange of correspondence with my State and Territory colleagues.

In essence, the Bill provides arrangements for nationally uniform proportionate reductions in the level of supplies of scarce liquid fuels, ensuring that the burden of a shortage is shared equitably as far as possible throughout Australia . This will be achieved by means of a 'bulk allocation' system for bulk consumers and, in extreme conditions, a rationing system for retail purchasers. It is intended that the bulk allocation system will operate with sufficient flexibility to meet special needs-such as seasonal and regional fluctuations in fuel requirements-and will take account of economic efficiency. This will ensure the maximum possible equity and efficiency in the distribution of fuel to consumers.

In addition to making supplies available to all users on a uniform basis, the Bill will also provide extra supplies of fuel to users whose activities are classified as 'essential' or 'high priority'. These will be identified by State and Territory energy Ministers for users in their regions and by the Commonwealth Minister for a limited range of Commonwealth responsibilities, such as Defence. To ensure consistency in the identification of essential and high priority users, and in the calculation of their allocation quantities, guidelines will be specified by the Commonwealth Minister. The formulation of these guidelines will be a subject of consultation between the State and Territory energy Ministers, and the guidelines will be presented to the Parliament for approval.

The Bill includes certain provisions for pre-emergency contingency planning, and this will be undertaken in co-operation with the appropriate State and Territory authorities, Ministers, and governments, with inputs from the oil industry and fuel users. Included in the contingency preparations are provisions for the maintenance of minimum stock levels to be held by oil industry in normal or non-emergency conditions.

In order to ensure that fuel is available to supply users during an emergency, the Bill provides powers to direct the movement, production, release or retention of liquid fuels if this becomes necessary. Directions under these powers can only be made after consultation with State and Territory energy Ministers.

In accordance with recent Government legislation in related areas, the Bill contains provisions for the reconsideration and review of certain ministerial decision. These include the determination of bulk customers, the identification by the Commonwealth of essential or high priority users, and directions on strategic stock levels. This protection of individuals and corporations is encompassed in provisions requiring the Minister to reconsider such decisions, and for their subsequent review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
The Bill also provides appropriate protection for the operation of consistent State or Territory laws.

In conclusion, I will revert to an earlier theme. The Government has a clear responsibility to prepare contingency plans against a foreseeable national emergency. There can be no argument that in today's uncertain world a major oil supply crisis is a real possibility, and it is equally certain that such a crisis would have potentially serious social and economic consequences for us as Australians. This Bill, based on the recommendations of a high-level committee arrived at after two years consideration of expert advice, will provide the Commonwealth with the means of fulfilling its role as a co-operating partner with the States and the Territories to ensure that the impact of such a crisis is minimised. It recognises, and protects to an unusual extent in emergency legislation, the rights of individuals, corporations and the States and Territories, and has as its major objectives effective preparation, economic efficiency and equity.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING STATIONS LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Act 1964 and the Television Stations Licence Fees Act 1964 (which are both in the nature of taxing Acts) prescribe the annual licence fees which are payable by companies operating commercial radio and television stations licensed under the Broadcasting and Television Act .

A flat fee of $500 is payable on the grant of any new station licence. Thereafter, each station is required to pay, on the anniversary of the grant of its licence, a fee calculated on the basis of a rising percentage of its annual gross earnings (AGE) from radio or television transmissions during the immediately preceding financial year. When the current progressive fee scale was set in 1981, the amending Acts prescribed ceilings upon the maximum fee rates payable by television stations (7.5 per cent) and by radio stations (5 per cent) .

The main purpose of imposing a fee on companies licensed to earn income from broadcasting is to contribute to overall Commonwealth revenues. Changes contained in this Bill and its counterpart, the Television Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill, which I will introduce shortly, will raise an additional $2.4 million in 1983-84. $40,000 of this increase will result from changes to the fee schedule for broadcasting stations.

The Government is concerned that due notice is taken of the ability of the broadcasting industry to pay. Accordingly, the measures contained in this Bill will affect only one station-the station with the highest turnover out of a total of 134.

The proposed changes to the fee scales consist of a small increase in licence fee rates for radio stations with Average Gross Earnings in excess of $9 million and an increase in the maximum licence fee rates payable from 5 per cent to 5.5 per cent of average gross earnings. These changes will be effective from 1 September 1983. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: TELEVISION STATIONS LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Television Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill, the companion measure to the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill, will increase revenue from licence fees by about $2.36 million in 1983-84.

The Government is concerned that due notice should be taken of the ability of the television industry to pay. Accordingly, the measures contained in this Bill will affect the 16 stations, out of a total of 50 commercial television stations , with the highest turnovers.

The proposed changes to the fee scales consist of a small increase in licence fee rates for television stations with average gross earnings in excess of $9 million and an increase in the maximum licence fee rates payable by television stations from 7.5 per cent to 8.0 per cent of average gross earnings. These changes will be effective from 1 September 1983.

The Government is concerned to achieve the maximum possible Australian content in respect of films and television programs. The Government will be considering proposals to encourage production of Australian programs, particularly proposals which are in the nature of offsets to the licence fee increases. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The primary purpose of this Bill is to facilitate the introduction of the Government's community employment program in the Public Service.

The community employment program is the Government's major job creation program which, when fully operational, is expected to create up to 70,000 new jobs nationally in a year on worthwhile community projects. Project jobs will have a duration of between three and 12 months, with an average job duration of around six months.

Nationally, $300m of Federal funds is to be made available for CEP during 1983- 84. $250m of this is to be apportioned to voluntary organisations, local authorities and State government departments and authorities, with the balance of $50m being made available to Federal departments and authorities.

Thus, whilst the major part of expenditure for the program will be through State, local government and voluntary agencies, it is the Government's intention that a leading role will be played by Commonwealth departments and authorities.

The aim of the community employment program is to provide employment for those most in need of it preference being given to those who have been registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service for nine months or more.
