TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 3 June 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many experiemnts on living animals were performed during the years 1980 , 1981 and 1982.
(2) How many experiments on living animals performed in 1982 were for the following purposes:
(a) the testing of cosmetics and toiletries;
(b) the testing of weapons;
(c) the testing of weedkillers;
(d) the testing of oven cleaners;
(e) the testing of pesticides;
(f) the testing of detergents;
(g) the testing of fertilizers; and
(h) the testing of tobacco.
(3) How many experiments on living animals were performed in 1982 which involved the killing of animals in the LD50 procedure.
(4) What steps are taken to inspect laboratories where animals are used and to ensure compliance with the Codes of Practice issued by the funding bodies.
(5) How many experiments on living animals were performed in Australia in 1982 involving the Draize test or other procedures causing damage to or destruction of skin or eye of animals.
(6) How many animals of the following species died in experiments during 1982: (a) rats, (b) dogs, (c) chickens, (d) sheep, (e) cats, (f) guinea pigs, (g) monkeys, (h) mice, (j) horses.

(7) What steps are taken to ensure compliance with the Codes of Practice for the Care and Use of Animals in Research in Australia issued by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation.
(8) What plans are there to ensure that all experiments upon living animals are performed by licensed scientists at registered and inspected laboratories as in Britain and other countries.
(9) How many primates were imported into Australia for research purposes in 1982.

(10) What steps are being taken to ensure that humane alternative techniques such as the use of tissue cultures or the Ames test are being used wherever practical. What funds are being channelled into collating and disseminating information about such humane techniques and developing new ones.
(11) How many animals died in experiments conducted by the following commercial interests in Australia in 1980, 1981 and 1982: Upjohn, Pfizer, Wellcome, ICI and Ciba-Geigy.
(12) What steps are being taken to limit animal experimentation to genuine medical purposes only.
(13) What steps are being taken to control the infliction of pain and distress experienced by research animals.

(14) What plans are there to increase the official statistics and information published concerning the use of living animals and in particular, are steps being taken to publish the number of animals by species, the purposes for which they are being used, the qualifications of the experimenters, and the severity of procedures being inflicted upon the animals.
(15) How many experiments on animals involved the use of electric shock or other aversive stimuli.
(16) How many experiments on animals in 1980, 1981 and 1982 involved the blinding or deafening of animals.
(17) What proportion of experiments on living animals performed in 1980, 1981 and 1982 were carried out without anaesthetic.

(18) What steps are being taken to ensure that all scientists experimenting on living animals in Australia are trained in humane animal care and the techniques of anaesthesia, euthanasia and analgesia before being allowed to experiment.
(19) How many animals in experiments in 1980, 1981 and 1982 were subjected to burning, scalding, or radiation.
(20) How many dogs and cats obtained from pounds were used for experimentation in 1980, 1981 and 1982.
(21) How many animals have been used at the Commonwealth Serum Laboratory in the preparation of funnel-web spider serum, of what species, and what procedures have been employed.

(22) What proportion of experiments on living animals performed in 1982 were affected by the guidelines laid down by the CSIRO Code of Practice, and what steps were taken to ensure that they were enforced.
(23) What reports of experiments on animals are publicly available.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Legislative requirements for experiments on living animals differ from State to State and nationwide statistics are not collected. I have no responsibility for any Commonwealth legislation in this area but the Minister for Territories and Local Government is responsible for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Ordinance 1959, in the Australian Capital Territory. Under that Ordinance the Minister for Health has recently empowered the Chairman of the Capital Territory Health Commission to authorise persons to perform experiments on animals.
Information concerning CSIRO's current holdings of animals is given in my answer to House of Representatives Question 236.

Relevant statistical and other information has been provided by previous Ministers for Health, and Science and Technology, in response to recent Questions on Notice. The responses are to be found in the following House of Representatives' Hansards:

(4) Inspection of laboratories is undertaken in some States by officers authorized under the relevant legislation. Where compliance with a code of practice is a condition of funding such adherence is a matter for the laboratory and the research worker(s) concerned.
It is mandatory for recipients of National Health and Medical Research Council grants to comply with the CSIRO 'Code of Practice for the Care and Use of Animals in Research in Australia'.

Those receiving grants from the Australian Research Grants Scheme (ARGS) have to comply with the codes of conduct enforced at their host institutions. However , my Department recognised earlier this year that it would be desirable to bind recipients of ARGS grants to the NH&MRC CSIRO Code more formally and arrangements are in hand to write the requirement into the terms and conditions of future ARGS awards.

In the past, some rural industry research fund committees had adopted the NH& MRC CSIRO Code, others had not. The Department of Primary Industry, which is responsible for oversight of these funds, has now ensured that all animal research funded through the following Committees will be subject to ethical evaluation and adherence to the NH&MRC CSIRO Code.

It is the policy of the CSIRO Executive that all experiments conducted by officers of the Organization involving animals must conform with the NH&MRC/ CSIRO Code. The Code has also been adopted by the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, the Commonwealth Institute of Health and the National Biological Standards Laboratory.
(7) Apart from the cases detailed in (4) above compliance with the NH&MRC/CSIRO Code by research institutions is voluntary.
(8) I am not aware of any plans.
(9) In 1982-83 there were 155 non-human primates imported for scientific purposes.

(10) I am advised that scientific institutions are giving increasing attention to finding alternatives to the use of animals for experimental purposes. Apart from the important humane aspects, this is occurring because the behaviour and reactions of live animals often fall short of experimental requirements and their use can be very expensive. Tissue culture, cell culture and other in vitro procedures and chemical tests are used extensively and have substantially reduced the use of animals in many situations.

The Institute of Laboratory Animal Resources of the United States National Academy of Sciences reported in 1980 that there had been a 35 per cent decline in the number of laboratory animals acquired by United States research organizations between 1968 and 1978-the use of dogs and cats decreased by 32 per cent and the use of non-human primates by 47 per cent. These figures confirm that the use of alternative techniques is increasing. Such alternative approaches are being promulgated through normal scientific contacts and publications. I am not aware of specific Government funding for the development of alternative techniques or the dissemination of information about such techniques.

(12) I am not aware of such steps. I would be concerned that limiting animal experimentation to human medicine would eliminate the research directed toward the control and prevention of domestic and native animal diseases. Further, it would also eliminate research aimed at improving domestic animal husbandry, and the conservation and management of native and introduced fauna.

(13) The adoption of the NH&MRC/CSIRO Code by research agencies and their compliance with relevant State and Territory legislation will help to ensure that no avoidable pain or distress is experienced by research animals, and that what they do experience is minimised.
(14) I am not aware of such plans or steps.

(15) Nationwide statistics are not collected. However, a few years ago the Australian Veterinary Association asked CSIRO to evaluate an electronic device used to restrain large domestic animals and, more particularly, to evaluate claims that the device suppressed pain in surgery. Details of this work will be found in September 1983 issue of the CSIRO quarterly 'Rural Research'.

(18) Many experiments simply involve observation of animals in captivity or in the wild without any manipulation, surgical or otherwise. Thus in many instances the question of anaesthesia, euthanasia and analgesia is irrelevant. Adoption of the NH&MRC/CSIRO Code by research agencies and their compliance with relevant State and Territory legislation will help to ensure that research workers are appropriately trained in humane animal care and that high standards of animal care are maintained at all times.

(21) Eleven rabbits, 900 mice and 6 monkeys have been used in the preparation of two batches of Funnel Web Spider Antivenom. The rabbits in which the antisera are raised are maintained as blood donors, the mice are used in the biological assay in a test resembling the LD50 test, and the monkeys are used in the safety tests. In addition some 23 monkeys were used in the research studies which established the feasibility of preparation of a Funnel Web Spider Antivenom.

(23) The reports of Commonwealth and State research agencies which, inter alia, indicate broadly the type of animal experimentation undertaken are usually publicly available. These reports contain lists of scientific papers which describe the nature of the experiments and their results.
The above issues might be more thoroughly traversed at a Senate Select Committee inquiry into animal welfare and rights as recently foreshadowed ( Senate Hansard, 19 May, 1983, pages 612-3 refer).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 24 August 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are trade certificates earned through theoretical and practical training in the armed services equal to trade certificates earned in civilian life.
(2) Are the courses offered in the services, and skills gained, equivalent to those courses offered and skills gained by non-forces men and women.
(3) Are the courses offered and certificates gained recognised as equal to those offered in civilian life.
(4) Can an ex-serviceman or woman gain a job of equal trade status once they leave the Service.
(5) If their trade is not recognised, why is this so.
(6) Are Service tradesmen on a par in terms of pay with their civilian counterparts.
(7) Are the teachers-instructors in the Services required to have special qualifications in the particular trade or trades in which they give instruction.
(8) Do Service personnel receive any special financial increments for the certificates they hold, or the skills they have gained.
(9) Upon entering the services, are the recruits informed that any certificates they gain will be of value to them when/if they return to civilian life in gaining employment in their chosen field.
(10) If there is a lack of appropriate trade recognition, what is being done to address this problem.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Parts 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 10 of the senator's question, although of concern, go beyond the scope of the Defence portfolio which does not have responsibility for these broader civilian workforce-related matters and the associated mechanisms for consultation with State authorities. I have, nevertheless, provided answers to those questions as I understand the situation. Should more definitive answers be required, it is suggested that they be addressed to my colleague the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations.
(1) It is worthy of note that recognition as a tradesman by one State is accepted across the Commonwealth. Four categories of armed Service apprentices and trainees can be identified:
(a) Army apprentices in Victorian proclaimed trades are registered with the Victorian Industrial Training Commission and receive the same trade certificates as civilian apprentices.

(b) Navy apprentices and adult trainees in New South Wales proclaimed trades are registered with the Apprenticeship Directorate in New South Wales and receive the same trade certificates as civilian apprentices.
(c) Air Force apprentices are not registered with any apprenticeship authority and consequently do not receive the same apprenticeship certificate as their civilian counterparts.

Recently arrangements have been made under the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation- TRR-Act to issue tradesmen's certificates to ex-Royal Australian Air Force apprentices in certain metal and electrical trades provided that they meet established criteria.
Apprentices in trades which are not TRR Act trades but which are proclaimed trades in certain States may also gain recognition.
(d) Army and Air Force Adult trainees may on discharge receive civilian recognition depending on their trades:

(i) In certain metal and electrical trades, an ex-serviceman who has met the criteria established under the TRR Act may be issued with a tradesman's certificate which would be recognised by employers and unions throughout Australia as equivalent to a completed apprenticeship contract.
(ii) In trades outside those covered by the TRR Act, there is no national recognition machinery.

However, in proclaimed apprenticeship trades in some States, ex-servicemen may be able to get some form of tradesman accreditation under recently enacted legislation. It is understood that Victoria, New South Wales, and Queensland have such legislation.
In trades which are specific to the armed services, no civilian equivalent to the Service certificate exists.
(2) Courses offered and skills gained in the services can be compared with those for non-forces men and women only through specific investigation by a competent recognition body.
For certain metal and electrical trades, such investigations have been carried out by central trades committees established under the TRR Act, and criteria for recognition have been determined.
In other cases apprenticeships which are registered with State apprenticeship or industrial training authorities are deemed equivalent to civilian apprenticeships.
Similarly some Service courses are recognised by individual technical and further education institutions as equivalent to their certificate courses.
Some specific trade courses offered and skills developed in the Services have not yet been assessed.

(3) Army and Navy apprentices and Navy adult trainees, because of registration of their indentures with State authorities, have full recognition in civilian life. The other two categories, i.e. Air Force apprentices and Army and Air Force adult trainees, can gain formal recognition through the TRR Act where the Act applies.

The TRR Act provides for central and local trade committees which represent unions, government and employers. The Committees grant accreditation in the form of a tradesman's certificate which indicates acceptance for employment at trade level by virtue of the agreement of employers and unions that the tradesman's certificate is equivalent in standard to a completed apprenticeship contract or indenture. The TRR Act deals only with specified metal and electrical trades.
(4) The ability of ex-servicemen or women to gain jobs of equal trade status once they leave the Service depends mainly on each individual.

Employers are not obliged to restrict trade employment to recognised tradesmen. Consequently, ex-service personnel may be able to gain employment at an equal or higher status despite the non-recognition of their trades skills because of lack of civil equivalence of their Service training. However, in some trades, e.g. plumbing, special licences are required.
(5) There are several reasons why a particular Service trade is not recognised formally in civilian industry; for example:
(i) The Service trade may have no equivalent in civilian industry;
(ii) The Service trade may not be sufficiently similar to the nearest civilian trade to enable an equivalence to be determined; or

(iii) There may be no machinery at Commonwealth or State level for providing formal recognition in the trade concerned. This would apply equally to servicemen and to civilians such as newly arrived migrants or refugees. The TRR Act is concerned with certain electrical and metal trades only.
In general formal recognition of trade qualifications obtained outside the apprenticeship system in Australia is the exception rather than the rule.

(6) The pay level system is fundamental to the concept of the armed forces ' industry' in which the cohesion and requirements of the Defence Force are central to salary fixation. The pay level system reflects the relative worth of each Service employment in terms of its functions, skills, training and responsibilities and, in a very broad way, civilian standards of remuneration. There are currently seven pay levels to reflect the various trades skills ranging from the 'minimum skilled' to the 'highest skilled or technician' level. These pay levels are subject to regular review by a special committee.
(7) Service teachers-instructors are either qualified professional teachers of the Education Branch or Corps or are tradesmen who have particular qualifications and trade skills.

(8) The grant of civilian certificates is not recognised by increments in pay. However, in certain employment categories, and notably in the technical categories, the achievement of higher Service-related skills and experience is recognised by the allocation of a higher skill grade and a consequent higher pay level. However within a particular trade any increments relate to skill levels during the training phase and once qualified at the tradesman's level further increments are related to rank rather than levels of skill. Minor differences exist between the three Services.

(9) In general, recruiting brochures and other aids at recruiting centres advise new recruits of the civilian trade certificates they will gain and the benefit they confer after discharge. Some unintentional exceptions to this practice may exist, but in general efforts are made to alert recruits to these matters.

(10) In preliminary meetings between officers of my Department, the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations and the Public Service Board it was agreed that further joint investigation to facilitate and improve civilian recognition is warranted and that the more immediate problem was centred in the middle level-TAFE Certificate-area. Since all three Services are involved any comprehensive investigation would require considerable effort and co-ordination. Recently I wrote to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations requesting that an interdepartmental working party be set up for this purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 August 1983 (Hansard, page 132), Senator Mason asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Will the Government make an immediate approach to the Indonesian Government for an absolute guarantee that no items included in Australian military aid to Indonesia will be used against the people of East Timor? Will the Government, while still pressing for an act of self-determination in East Timor, seek as an interim measure a full and permanent amnesty for those Timorese who have opposed the Indonesian invasion? Will the Government seek, through the good offices of the United Nations and with the concurrence of the Indonesian and other interested governments, an open door for a comprehensive pattern of aid for East Timor in the form of both money and expertise that would enable it to become a prosperous and viable society? If that last objective could be achieved, and I believe it could, can that be on the basis of normal disclosure of events in East Timor being permitted by the Indonesian Government so that world opinion can be satified as to the intentions of Indonesia in regard to East Timor?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to those parts of the honourable senator's question which fall within his area of responsibility:

The Indonesian Government has been offering amnesty to Fretilin guerillas and their supporters since December 1977. The most recent offer was made in July of this year. The Indonesian authorities have emphasised that reprisals will not be taken against those who accept the amnesty offer. While precise information on the number of people who have availed themselves of the amnesty is not available , the policy has had some success in encouraging people to leave the mountains and return to a more normal way of life.

The reduction in the number of Fretilin sympathisers detained on Atauro Island is similarly to be welcomed. At the end of April 1983, 2,800 detainees were still on Atauro-against an initial population of around 5,000. The bulk of these detainees have been resettled in their former villages or in other villages on the mainland.
It is hoped that the remaining detainees on Atauro will be transferred to the mainland by the end of the year.

The Australian Government welcomes the efforts at reconciliation that have been made in East Timor by Governor Mario Carrascalao. It is therefore with regret that the Government learned of the attack on 8 April on an Indonesian garrison near Dilor in which 12 to 15 Indonesian soldiers were killed.

The Government believes that a resumption of military hostilities in East Timor would represent a step backwards in the search for a lasting peace. The Government therefore urges restraint so that the process of peaceful contact can be given a chance to succeed.

As regards the establishment of an 'open door' policy for the provision of international aid to East Timor, it should be noted that the International Committee of the Red Cross, United Nations International Childrens Emergency Fund, the United States Catholic Relief Services and the Australian Government have been providing aid to East Timor for many years. For example, Australian Government assistance since September 1975 amounts to $7.7m. The most recent contribution, amounting to $1.5m, was announced by the Prime Minister in June.

While the Government sees advantages in Senator Mason's suggestion, the Indonesian authorities have to date preferred to initiate their own development budget of US $83m in 1982-83, and to limit outside assistance to support for humanitarian relief programs delivered through international relief agencies and some voluntary organisations. A number of recent visitors to East Timor, including an Australian parliamentary delegation, have attested to the considerable economic and social progress that has been achieved in recent years .

The Government has welcomed the fact that in recent years the Indonesian authorities have permitted an increasing number of visitors to East Timor. While wishing to see this continue, the Government recognises that the question of access is ultimately one for the Indonesian authorities to decide. In this context, the Government welcomes the recent visit to East Timor of an Australian parliamentary delegation and the excellent arrangements that were made for the delegation to enable it to travel so widely in East Timor.
